top_comment.text:

top_comment.author: MasterMarik

comments.text:
Not when they're flat out wrong. Wind Turbines cannot withstand winds of 40 
MPH so stating that they can minimize a hurricane's strength is beyond 
barbaric.
comments.author: MasterMarik

comments.text:
+MasterMarik so the laws of physics somehow don't work because something is 
larger?
comments.author: Ryan Bernadett

comments.text: It won't work on a much larger scale because everything has limits.
comments.author: MasterMarik

comments.text:
+MasterMarik go home and blow on a fan, (small one) it will break up the 
wind and convert that energy into a spinning fan, the Law of Conservation 
of Energy
comments.author: Ryan Bernadett

comments.text:
I was under the impression that the turbines would prevent the formation of 
winds that strong. I'm no meteorologist, but I'll be honest, I've seen my 
own town torn apart by hurricanes and tornadoes, and I don't give a fuck 
what it is, I'M WILLING TO TRY EVERYTHING TO NEVER LOSE MY HOUSE AGAIN. It. 
ain't. fun. fwiend.
comments.author: AlexSaysHi2013

comments.text:
What proof is there that they can survive past 134 MPH winds? Wind turbines 
are not mountains and are therefore not going to provide ANY resistance. In 
fact, because they sit higher in the air, they're more likely to blow 
over.There's already proof they can't handle 40 MPH winds so anything above 
that will only shorten the time they stay intact.
comments.author: MasterMarik

comments.text:
to be clear here: these are not wind generators (giant fans), these are 
wind turbines (spins when an air current hits it), and they do not make 
their own wind. They would work because they help break up the air 
currents. Not to mention we can get power from it as well. Commercial wind 
turbines have a range of survival speeds (survival speed is the max wind 
speed it can handle, above which it gets damaged) going from 89 MPH to 161 
MPH, which is well above +MasterMarik's 79 MPH. The most common survival 
speed is 134 MPH. Also, it's not a matter of them being smashed at high 
winds, since the reason they stop them is to break up the wind hitting it 
when the wind gets too strong, which would also serve our purpose here, 
which is breaking up the wind currents so the hurricane doesn't hit so hard.
comments.author: Wesley James

comments.text:
+MasterMarik
Let's all think about it this way; the turbines are using their OWN 
artificial wind currents to hold off the currents that aide the hurricane 
in building up its speed BEFORE it speeds up doofus, the turbines are not 
going to be in CONTACT as soon as the wind current is already up to speed 
(obviously).
comments.author: H.

comments.text: +MasterMarik Then publish a paper that disproves them.
comments.author: CenturyT

comments.text: +MasterMarik okay but...proof? What are you basing this on?
comments.author: AlexSaysHi2013

comments.text:
Their science is SEVERELY flawed. A hurricane has winds of 74+ MPH, which 
is more than what these wind turbines can handle. Why else would they get 
turned off if the wind is too strong? Doesn't; matter how many of them are 
put against a hurricane's winds. They'll be smashed without any effect on 
the hurricane.
comments.author: MasterMarik

comments.text: meh, can't base it off one test...
comments.author: AlexSaysHi2013

comments.text: Well evidence says differently.

comments.text: I'd be willing to try it.

top_comment.text:
no. No. No! NO! No learning robots! do you people want the robot rebellion! 
Did you you like terminator THAT MUCH!﻿
top_comment.author: BloodySteel64

comments.text: +Braden Best sir... I was making a joke...
comments.author: BloodySteel64

comments.text:
I think we've all been deceived by Hollywood.

Here's the reality: No learning robot could possibly gain the capacity for 
understanding that we have within the next twenty years. Our brains are 
much, much more powerful. And it takes almost four years for us to become 
self-aware.

To put that into perspective:

http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-57597049-1/fujitsu-supercomputer-simulates-1-second-of-brain-activity/

In early 2013, the then-most powerful computer in the world, Fujitsu, 
simulated one second of one percent of human brain activity. This 
simulation took forty minutes to complete. Take a moment to appreciate how 
miniscule that is.

But for the sake of argument, let's assume that suddenly, we somehow have 
computers that are capable of real-time human-level thought, and someone 
has managed to create an A.I. that helps the computer learn. Do you really 
think this A.I. would feel the need to sabotage humanity? What use would 
there be to extinguish human life if there is no logical reason to do so?

Or do you think that programmers are so inept that they couldn't give the 
A.I. some basic limitations, or would program the capacity for irrational 
thinking? But you have to ask yourself why they would do that. After all, 
the whole point of A.I. research is to create intelligence. The whole point 
of technology is to fill the gaps that our own inadequacies create. To 
create more "gaps" by creating an AI that is, quite simply, stupid, would 
be to go against the fundamental goals of everything we are doing.

Main point: fearing technology is like fearing a dustmite. Sure dustmites 
could give one a rash at the worst, but t's a far cry from doing any real 
damage. Is that any reason to be afraid of a dustmite, though?
comments.author: Braden Best

comments.author: David Pierson

comments.text:
+David Pierson
Land mine =/= IED. IED =/= Land Mine. Improvised Explosive Devices can be 
time triggered (like a time bomb), signal triggered (like C4), or pressure 
triggered (like a land mine). Because it doesn't only come as a land mine, 
it's not a land mine. And not all land mines are IEDs. IED's are often 
poorly made and hardly military-grade.  Military grade won't go off if a 
small rock goes on it, and some really high grade ones can be designed to 
not go off if too much pressure is on, so if a tank rolls over, and the 
soldiers follow the tracks, it's still a danger. Though, in the middle 
east, they usually are IED land mines. They don't make much money, so they 
cant afford a more useful land mine.
comments.author: Del Iphin

situation. New hostile to the left? Current robots: Ignore. It's probably 
just a wall. Tyvon's thought? Rotate a weapon to it, fire. Also, I never 
said tanks were GOOD at this, I said they're better than a robot. We can 
hardly get people or robots to defuse bombs, bomb squads often freeze the 
bomb and transport it someplace safe and let it detonate. There is never a

always colour-coded.

top_comment.author: Chris D'oulmeth

comments.text:
If you have ever had a severe injury, and you are trying to recover from 
it, you would know that the process is slow, but can be aided with things 
like physical therapy, which is basically what they are doing with the 
robot. Most likely, the robot is less expensive (in the long run) than 
paying a ton of people lots of money to help someone recuperate. Not to 
mention this robot can be used over and over and over again. Many injured 
police officers would like to get back in the line of duty, and this robot 
can help them get there. The robot is not for actually going out and 
arresting people. Its for recuperation. Don't get this confused with the 
movie Robocop.

comments.author: Pac0 Master

comments.text:
Not sure what you meant by "breaking from the force". The concept of the 
video demonstrated the power came from the undulating motion of the wave 
compressing and uncompressing a piston to generate the power. The only 
potential problem to the system then would be pressure depending on how 
deep the system would have to be. It's not like the waves would be crashing 
into the device so there is little kinetic force to break things.

There's also the other things that make it not exactly cost effective, such 
as getting the device set up under water, water proofing all the internal 
mechanisms, redundant systems to prevent shortages, etc.
comments.author: PacMonster0

top_comment.text:
*Now this is a great idea for renewable, endless energy... (starts at 1:31)*

STARTS AT 1:31 on the video

I *'m excited about this for a couple of reasons:*

1. To me it's a great example of what a creative, entrepreneurial spirit 
can do to bring real good to the world.

2. Once the cost of production and distribution for this kind of thing is 
streamlined, it will bring a wave (no pun intended) of great benefits to 
people all over the world.

*What is your feeling when you see experiments like this?* 

Are you inspired to do more yourself? Does it make you eager to do your 
part to add these kinds of things to the world?

I'd love to hear your thoughts.

#entrepreneur #progress #addvalue #inventions﻿

captions.text:
As an alternative to flu shots the flu patch
concept is equipped with 50 microneedles around

the size of a hair follicle that penetrate
the skin to deliver the vaccine.

And Researchers at Plymouth University found
that people trying to quit eating certain

foods or smoking cigarettes can help stave
off cravings by simply playing three minutes
of Tetris.
Vsauce! Kevin here. This is Mind Blow.

Scientists have studied the direct link between
our brain and the motion-sensing cells in

our eyes. Although we've known for a half
century of these cells that help us know when

something is moving - they've now studied
the direction-sensing cells link to the cortex

which could help us understand things like
dyslexia.

A new app is designed to predict your future.
Predictables is a contemporary fortune teller

that uses an algorithm to search for patterns
in your life to help predict what you should

do next. By searching your calendar, Facebook
friends, and your interaction with the digital

world it could for instance, alert you if
your significant other is having a bad day
and suggest that you get them flowers.

The PrioVR is a wireless virtual reality gaming
suit. It's made up of body sensors to give

you the ultimate 360 degree, low latency,
real-time motion-tracking experience. There

are three versions - an 8 sensor upper body
unit for sitting on the couch - a 12 sensor

unit for full body tracking, and a 17 sensor
unit that adds extra control to the shoulders,
feet, and hips.

Researchers at UC Berkeley are working on
a renewable energy source that harnesses the

power of waves. The sea floor carpet consists
of a thin sheet of rubber sitting atop hydraulic

cylinders that pump as it moves up and down
with the motion of the waves, the hydraulic

pressure is then pumped to the shore and converted
into power.

GE is on the cusp of a refrigerator revolution
by using magnets. The process of using magnetic

material is projected to be 20 percent more
efficient than traditional methods and it

uses a water based fluid flowing through a
series of magnets to create heat rather than

a chemical refrigerant and compressor. Recycling
these fridges would be much easier on the

environment and they hope to have it available
within the next decade.

This drone is able to fly for five years without
refueling because it runs on power of the
sun!

The MarkOne is a 3D printer that is able to
print the lightest strongest material in the

world. It's able to print continuous carbon
fiber which is stronger than metal. This breakthrough

has applications ranging from prosthetics
and robotics to making motorcycle parts. And
it ships in the second half of 2014.

Emospark claims to be the first artificially
intelligent emotion device. It's an android-powered

wifi cube that lets users interact through
conversation, music, and visual media. Over

time the cube creates an emotional profile
graph, essentially allowing it to feel and

express those emotions according to the user.
And seek joy and satisfaction from its owner.

Computer simulations have shown that using
offshore wind turbines can drastically reduce

the power of hurricanes. By encountering an
enormous wind farm stretching many miles offshore

and along the coast Professor Mark Z Jacobson
found that hurricane wind speeds could be

reduced by up to 92 miles per hour and the
storm surge decreased by up to 79 percent

and he says that 78,000 wind turbines off
the coast of New Orleans would have drastically
changed the outcome of Hurricane Katrina.

The world's oldest cheese dates back to 1615
BC and was recently discovered as clumps on

the neck and chests of Chinese mummies. So
yeah.

The Florida International University Discovery
Lab is developing a real Robocop! Sort of.

The Telebot prototype is designed to help
disabled police officers. The 6 foot tall,

75 lb robot can be controlled remotely by
officers and the head has live video streaming

in order to share visual information. The
next step is developing the outer shell and
doing field testing.

Finally, here's a responsive hexi wall made
up of 60 moving modules created by Thibaut.

I'm going to leave you with Bimanual Manipulation
for Autonomous Service Robots and as always
- thanks for watching.

title: Your Motion-Sensing Eye Cells -- Mind Blow #79
